attributes.title: Racially-Based Social Distancing and Outgroup Discomfort in Second Life
attributes.description: In this study, I will perform a secondary analysis on data collected by my research professor, John Tawa, to determine if there is a significant relationship between participants’ self-reported Outgroup Discomfort measurements (scale developed by Cole & Yip 2008) with the distance they create between themselves and online avatars. All data was collected through the online program Second Life (SL).This program allows users to create their own avatar (independent of how they actually look) and interact with other avatars controlled by people from around the world. In the current study, we used this platform as a means to assess social distancing from black avatars as a result of anti-black racism and how this experience affects the outgroup discomfort measures of the non-black users piloting black avatars.

q2.value:
H1: Participants will maintain greater social distance while operating a Black vs. non 
Black avatar.
H2: Outgroup Discomfort will mediate differences in social distancing when participants use a Black or non-Black avatar.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In this study, participants operated a randomly assigned avatar for the first 10 minutes and then a same-race avatar for 10 minutes. We first emailed all prospective participants a screener to see if they identified monoracially as either white, black or asian. If they did, we then scheduled a half hour time slot for them to individually come into the lab. During that time slot, a research assistant met the participant in the lobby and brought them into the lab. There, they sat at a computer with Second Life already on screen set to the virtual location, Frank’s Jazz Club. We chose this location because it is predominantly white and attracts many other Second Life users. Prior to any participants arriving, the research assistant on duty loaded Second Life, made sure that the program was working properly and rolled a die to decide what each participant’s non-racially self identified avatar would be. We created a total of three avatars, all named ‘Ashley’ who looked exactly alike apart from their perceived race.  Because each participant embodied both an avatar of their own race and of a randomly selected race, research assistants                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               assigned their first avatar based on a die roll (1-2 for White Ashley, 3-4 for Asian Ashley and 5-6 for Black Ashley). 
	After being seated, participants were then told that they would have two ten minute trials embodying two avatars with a break in between, then followed by an online survey. They were then introduced to their first, randomly selected avatar and shown the basic controls (how to walk and chat with others). Once the participant felt comfortable going forward, the research assistant would then set a timer for ten minutes and leave the room. Once the ten minutes were up, the research assistant returned and logged into the avatar that matched the participant’s self-identified race. The research assistant then set another timer for ten minutes and left the room until the trial was complete. 
	After returning for the second time, the research assistant would then log out of the Second Life program and have the participant take a racial beliefs and outgroup discomfort survey on another computer. Once participants finished both surveys they left the lab they received an email two weeks later asking them to complete both surveys again. When this was completed, participants would then receive either research credit or a $10 Amazon gift card as compensation.

q7.value: In order to determine which first-avatar participants were assigned, a die was rolled.  A roll of 1-2 for White Ashley, 3-4 for Asian Ashley and 5-6 for Black Ashley.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Participants were randomly assigned to operate same and different race avatars (see procedures).

Outgroup Discomfort
The Outgroup Discomfort scale I will use in this study originates from Cole and Yip's (2008) Outgroup Comfort scale.  In their study, they created a 16-point scale used to measure relative racial outgroup comfort among black and white college students. In this way, they termed outgroup comfort to be an advantageous trait that is predictive of resilience, confidence and improved mental health especially in black students (Cole & Yip 2008). They also found that one’s outgroup comfort measure was predictive of interracial contact. Because I am more interested in racial discomfort within the context of this study, however, I will be reverse coding all the items in this scale. In this current study, I will be using  measure (inversely coded) in combination with proxemics data to determine differences in racial social distancing. 

Social distance
	In order to measure social distance, we developed a script in Second Life that took a snapshot of how many avatars were within 5 meters of the embodied avatar.This script triggered about every ten seconds of gameplay. We then totaled and averaged how many avatars were within a 5 meter range for each 10 minute trial period. Because each participant had two ten minute trials, they each have two scores pertaining to the average number of avatars they came in contact with over a trial period.

H1:  My first hypothesis will be tested with a Repeated Measures ANOVA.
H2: My second hypothesis will be tested with a Within Group Mediation analysis.

attributes.title: Intragastric botulinum toxin A injection is an effective obesity therapy for patients with BMI > 40 kg/m2: a systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: The effect of intragastric injection of BTA remains debatable. In a previous meta-analysis, Bang et al. showed that intragastric injection of BTA was effective as a management of obesity. However, a meta-analysis concluded BTA therapy alone was not effective for the primary treatment of obesity. Therefore, we conducted this meta-analysis to assess the efficacy of intragastric botulinum toxin A injection with the aim of providing treatment recommendations to physicians in daily clinical practice.

q1.value: Ting-Wei Chang, Hong-Jie Jhou, Chih-Kun Huang, Po-Huang Chen, Po-Chih Chang

q2.value: We conducted this meta-analysis to assess the efficacy of intragastric botulinum toxin A injection with the aim of providing treatment recommendations to physicians in daily clinical practice.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Meta-analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: A comprehensive search was performed without language restrictions using PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library, and the Web of Science to identify available studies that evaluated the outcomes of injections of botulinum toxin in morbid obesity patients until April 01, 2020. We adhered to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta Analyses (PRISMA) for conducting systematic reviews and meta analyses of RCTs.

q11.value: 5 articles including met the inclusion criteria for meta-analysis after the full-text review.

question.value: We also extracted the following primary outcomes: 1) absolute weight loss was defined as the weight reduction after procedure; 2) body mass index change was defined as the body mass index change after procedure; and 3) gastric emptying time was measured as half empty time

We performed data analysis in accordance to  the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. The mean difference (MD) approach with 95% CIs was calculated using the generic inverse variance method to measure continuous outcomes, 
    	The I square (I2) statistic and Cochran's Q test was used to evaluate heterogeneity. I2 > 50% and Cochran's Q test P < 0.1 was considered statistically significant heterogeneity. A mixed-effects linear meta-regression model was conducted to assess the cause of heterogeneity for major outcomes with following variables: gender, body mass index, and baseline weight. Subgroup analysis was conducted to investigate clinical and statistical heterogeneity.
    	All meta-analyses were conducted using the “metafor” and “meta” packages of R software version 3.6.1 and the trial sequential analysis was done using the TSA program version version 0.9 beta (www.ctu.dk/tsa). A P value of 0.05 in a two-tailed test was considered statistical significance.

attributes.title: A comparison of adult memory for a single versus an instance of a repeated stressful event
attributes.description: This project is being conducted by a group of researchers at the University of Sydney - Natali Dilevski (PhD candidate), Dr Helen Paterson (Senior Lecturer) and Dr Celine van Golde (Lecturer). This project aims to investigate adult memory for repeated stressful events. 'Repeated events' refers to a type of event that has been experienced on more than one occasion and all consist of a common underlying structure. Repeated events are a common occurrence in such crimes as family and domestic violence. In this project we are specifically interested in investigating whether the memory reports for those that have experienced a repeated event contain less accurate information than those that have experienced a single event.

copyright_holders: Natali Dilevski; Helen Paterson; Celine van Golde

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: “Tell me about the time you remember the best” – Adult memory for single and repeated emotionally stressful events

other.value:
We had originally planned to conduct study 2 in the lab (like study 1). However, with the onset of COVID-19, we decided to conduct the study completely online to conform with social distancing measures.

We will compare emotional stress data both before and after the memory stimuli (i.e., the hypothetical relationship scenario task). These measures include: the positive and negative affect schedule – negative affect (PANAS-NA; Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988), and the state trait anxiety inventory-state (STAI-S; Spielberger, 1989). For the target scenario, we will conduct two 2 (time: time 1 score, time 2 score) x 3 (event frequency group) mixed-design ANOVAs with PANAS-NA and STAI-S scores as separate dependent variables. 

All participants will complete the DASS 21 scale (depression anxiety stress scales) at the beginning of session 1. This measure has been included to ensure that there are no baseline differences in depression, anxiety, or stress symptoms that might act as a confounding variable in the memory results. 

After each relationship scenario, participants will be asked to respond to several questions assessing the quality of participants subjective experience of the scenario. These measures will allow us to determine how good participants mental representation was for the target scenario. 

In the memory session, we will ask repeat-best participants to explain their reason(s) for selecting the event they did. We will report the main reason(s) identified by participants by extracting “themes” in their reasoning. We will also ask repeat-best participants to determine during which event/session they experienced the scenario they selected (i.e., event 1, event 2 etc.).

sample.value: Like study 1, we aim to collect 30-35 participants per group (N = ~ 90-105). Like study 1, all participants will be female.

analyses.value:
Free and cued recall memory analyses: A series of one-way ANOVAs will be conducted comparing differences in memory performance between the three groups for each of the outcome measures. If the omnibus ANOVA is significant, follow-up pairwise comparisons will be conducted using the Tukey HSD procedure. 

Recognition memory analyses: Two 3 (event frequency group) x 2 (lure type: confound, new) mixed-design ANOVAs will be conducted with memory sensitivity and response bias as separate dependent variables. Significant main or interaction effects will be explored further with contrast analysis.

outliers.value: There will be attention checks throughout the experiment. If participants fail one attention check, they will be removed from the sample.

dependent.value:
The primary outcome measure is memory performance for the target scenario. Memory will be tested using free recall, cued recall, and recognition questions. Below we outline the specific outcome measures that will be calculated.

The following variables will be calculated based on the free and cued recall data:
1)	Correct details (defined narrowly): any detail that was experienced in the target scenario only. 
2)	Correct details (defined broadly): any detail that was experienced in the target and non-target scenarios (i.e., correct details - defined narrowly + internal intrusion errors)
3)	Internal intrusion errors: any detail that was experienced during the non-target scenario. For those in the single event group, this type of error can occur by chance. 
4)	External intrusion errors: any detail that was never experienced.
5)	Proportion correct in recall (defined narrowly): correct details - defined narrowly / total number of reported details.
6)	Proportion correct in recall (defined broadly): correct details - defined broadly / total number of reported details.
7)	Don’t know responses (cued recall only)

For the recognition data we will use hit and false alarm rates to calculate measures based on signal detection theory: 
1)	Memory sensitivity (d’): the ability to discriminate between an experienced (i.e., studied item) and false detail (i.e., lure item).
2)	Response Bias (c): the tendency to response in a conservative/liberal manner to all items.

Memory sensitivity and response bias will be calculated based on the two type of lure items – confound items (statements/images from non-target scenarios), and new items (statements/images that were never experienced, but conceptually related to the scenarios).

conditions.value:
Similar to study 1, there are three experimental groups:
1)	Single event: Participants experience one domestic violence relationship scenario and complete the memory test based on that scenario.
2)	Repeated event – last: Participants experience four domestic violence relationship scenarios one-week a part and complete the memory test based on the last scenario.
3)	Repeated event – best: Participants experience four domestic violence scenarios one-week a part and complete the memory test based on the scenario they ‘remember the best’. This group will be instructed to determine which event they remember the best and then generate a label for that event. This label will then be used throughout the memory session to refer to that event.

hypothesis.value:
This study is a follow-up to “A comparison of adult memory for single versus an instance of a repeated stressful event.” This study (which we refer to as study 1) sought to investigate the difference between adult memory for a single event versus an instance of a repeated event. In particular, we investigated whether a ‘remember best’ memory prompt (i.e., recall details about a time remembered best) would help repeated-event participants particularize individual instances. 

Similar to study 1, our follow-up study (study 2) will consist of three event frequency groups:
1)	Single event: Participants experience one domestic violence relationship scenario and complete the memory test based on that scenario.
2)	Repeat-last: Participants experience four domestic violence relationship scenarios (order counterbalanced) one-week a part and complete the memory test based on the last scenario (i.e., event 4).
3)	Repeat-best: Participants experience four domestic violence scenarios (order counterbalanced) one-week a part and complete the memory test based on the scenario they ‘remember the best’. 

In study 1 and study 2 (the current study) the single event group and repeat-last group is exactly the same. The repeat-best groups in study 1 and 2 differ in how the ‘remember best’ prompt was/is delivered to participants. In study 1, participants were asked to nominate the scenario they remember best based on when it occurred (i.e., event 1, event 2 etc.). In study 2, participants will be instructed to determine which event they remember the best and then give it a label. This label will then be used to prompt memory throughout the memory session. We speculated that in study 1 by getting repeat-best participants to select an event based on when the scenario occurred it caused source confusion. Therefore, in study 2, we attempt to decrease source monitoring demands by having participants select an event based on what happened (label it) rather than when it happened. 

Hypotheses – free recall and cued recall:

Consistent with previous research, when memory accuracy is defined narrowly, we expect that the repeat-last group will be less capable of particularizing the target scenario than the single event group (Dilevski, Paterson, & van Golde, 2020; Woiwod et al., 2018). We expect that the repeat-best group and single event group will be similarly capable of particularising the target scenario. However, we expect the repeat-best group to be better able to particularise the target scenario compared to the repeat-last group. 

When memory accuracy is defined broadly, we expect that the three groups will not differ from one another. 

Hypotheses – recognition:

Similar to study 1, we expect no difference in memory sensitivity between the single event group and repeat-best group. However, we expect the single and repeat-best groups to have a higher rate of memory sensitivity than the repeat-last group. We expect this pattern of findings to be similar for confound and new lure items. 

Consistent with previous research, we expect no differences in response bias between the event frequency groups (e.g., Dilevski, Paterson, & van Golde, 2020; Woiwod et al., 2018).

Similar to study 1, there are three experimental groups:
1)	Single event: Participants experience one domestic violence relationship scenario and complete the memory test based on that scenario.
2)	Repeated event – last: Participants experience four domestic violence relationship scenarios one-week a part and complete the memory test based on the last scenario.
3)	Repeated event – best: Participants experience four domestic violence scenarios one-week a part and complete the memory test based on the scenario they ‘remember the best’. This group will be instructed to determine which event they remember the best and then generate a label for that event. This label will then be used throughout the memory session to refer to that event.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
This study is a follow-up to “A comparison of adult memory for single versus an instance of a repeated stressful event.” This study (which we refer to as study 1) sought to investigate the difference between adult memory for a single event versus an instance of a repeated event. In particular, we investigated whether a ‘remember best’ memory prompt (i.e., recall details about a time remembered best) would help repeated-event participants particularize individual instances. 

Similar to study 1, our follow-up study (study 2) will consist of three event frequency groups:
1)	Single event: Participants experience one domestic violence relationship scenario and complete the memory test based on that scenario.
2)	Repeat-last: Participants experience four domestic violence relationship scenarios (order counterbalanced) one-week a part and complete the memory test based on the last scenario (i.e., event 4).
3)	Repeat-best: Participants experience four domestic violence scenarios (order counterbalanced) one-week a part and complete the memory test based on the scenario they ‘remember the best’. 

In study 1 and study 2 (the current study) the single event group and repeat-last group is exactly the same. The repeat-best groups in study 1 and 2 differ in how the ‘remember best’ prompt was/is delivered to participants. In study 1, participants were asked to nominate the scenario they remember best based on when it occurred (i.e., event 1, event 2 etc.). In study 2, participants will be instructed to determine which event they remember the best and then give it a label. This label will then be used to prompt memory throughout the memory session. We speculated that in study 1 by getting repeat-best participants to select an event based on when the scenario occurred it caused source confusion. Therefore, in study 2, we attempt to decrease source monitoring demands by having participants select an event based on what happened (label it) rather than when it happened. 

Hypotheses – free recall and cued recall:

Consistent with previous research, when memory accuracy is defined narrowly, we expect that the repeat-last group will be less capable of particularizing the target scenario than the single event group (Dilevski, Paterson, & van Golde, 2020; Woiwod et al., 2018). We expect that the repeat-best group and single event group will be similarly capable of particularising the target scenario. However, we expect the repeat-best group to be better able to particularise the target scenario compared to the repeat-last group. 

When memory accuracy is defined broadly, we expect that the three groups will not differ from one another. 

Hypotheses – recognition:

Similar to study 1, we expect no difference in memory sensitivity between the single event group and repeat-best group. However, we expect the single and repeat-best groups to have a higher rate of memory sensitivity than the repeat-last group. We expect this pattern of findings to be similar for confound and new lure items. 

Consistent with previous research, we expect no differences in response bias between the event frequency groups (e.g., Dilevski, Paterson, & van Golde, 2020; Woiwod et al., 2018).

attributes.title: Political Memes
attributes.description:
Participants were presented with one conservative meme and one liberal meme. Conservative memes were taken from a relatively popular conservative subreddit (r/Conservative: https://www.reddit.com/r/Conservative/top/?t=all) and liberal memes were taken from a popular subreddit (r/Political Humor: https://www.reddit.com/r/PoliticalHumor/top/?t=all), which is more left-leaning. They were then asked to answer the same series of questions for each meme (e.g. how funny they found the meme, how apt the captions were, how relatable they found the meme, how much they agreed with the message, etc.). They were then asked to answer a few questions about their own political views; he 12 Item Social and Economic Conservatism Scale (Everett, 2013) was used to measure participants' political views. Participants were also asked to report how they identified politically. 

The main research question in this study is to see which factors predict people's ratings of humor and comprehensibility when viewing political memes. This project is an extension of two previous studies done in the lab on non-political memes.

q2.value:
1. Greater rated aptness will predict greater rated humor.
2. Greater rated relatability will predicted greater rated humor.
3. Greater rated surprising ness of captions will predict greater rated humor. 

4. Greater rated aptness will predict greater rated comprehensibility. 
5. Greater rated relatability will predict greater rated comprehensibility. 

6. Greater rated agreement, relatability, surprising ness, funniness, and aptness will predict greater likelihood of sharing the meme with friends and family. 
7. Conservatives (as measured through scale and self report) will agree more with messages conveyed in conservative memes, and liberals (as measured through scale and self report) will agree more with messages conveyed in liberal memes. 

8. Agreement with the message will positively affect relatability which will positively affect aptness (assuming causality for mediation analysis -- aware that design does not allow for true causal statement). 
9. Agreement with the message will positively affect relatability, which will positively affect aptness, which will positively affect comprehensibility and humor of the meme. 

10. When responding to an incongruent meme (e.g. liberal responding to a conservative meme), factors like relatability and aptness won't be positively related to rated comprehension or humor. However, when responding to a congruent meme (e.g. liberal responding to a liberal meme), factors like relatability and aptness will be positively related to rated comprehension or humor.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This survey will follow a within-subjects, repeated measures design; it will be administered using Qualtrics. Once the participants consent to participating in the study, the survey will randomly assign them to either counterbalancing condition 1 or 2. In counterbalancing condition 1, they will first see (at random) one of the twelve possible liberal memes. They will then answer a series of question about that meme. Then, they will see (at random) one of the twelve possible conservative memes. They will then answer the same series of questions about that meme. In counterbalancing condition two, the order is simply flipped (sees a conservative meme first followed by a liberal meme). 

After participants see and respond to questions about the two memes, they will complete the 12-item scale to measure social and economic conservatism. They will then be asked how they personally identify, political (options are: extremely conservative, moderately conservative, moderately liberal, extremely liberal, libertarian, independent). We will also ask them for their age and gender identity. 

That concludes the survey. Attached below are:
* political scale.docx : this is a word document of the 12-item scale (Everett, 2013)
* Liberal memes.docx : this is a word document of the 12 liberal memes. The document also indicates the number of net upvotes each meme received at the time of collection. 
* Conservative memes.docx : this is a word document of the 12 conservative memes. Like the liberal memes, the document includes the number of net upvotes each meme received at the time of collection. 
* Questions.docx : is a document containing the series of questions participants were asked after seeing each meme. The questions were the same for both memes, and were always in this order.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned (using random number generator in Qualtrics to generate embedded data) into one of two counterbalancing conditions. Participants were also randomly presented one of each of the two memes (conservative and liberal). The randomization function was used in Qualtrics ("Randomly present 1 of the following:")

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Subjects will be recruited through Amazon's Mechanical Turk. Participants who have participated in either of the two previous meme studies (were not pre-registered) are not able to participate in the current study.

Subjects must either identify as politically liberal or politically conservative (excluding libertarians and independents for this study). This will be done by supplying a link to the survey that restricts participants to being liberal, and another link that is restricted to conservative participants. 

Subjects will be awarded $2 for participating in the survey (15 minutes).

q12.value: We would like each meme to be rated 10 times by liberals and 10 times by conservatives. Therefore, we need to sample 120 individuals from each leaning to accomplish that. Therefore, we need a total of 240 useable observations. To account for any faulty data, we will collect an extra 24 observations from liberals and another 24 from conservatives. This will result in a total of 288 observations.

q13.value: Amazon's Mechanical Turk allows us to set the stopping rule.

question.value: NA
Documents (political scale.docx and Questions.docx) containing all the questions are attached.

1. Greater rated aptness will predict greater rated humor.
2. Greater rated relatability will predicted greater rated humor.
3. Greater rated surprising ness of captions will predict greater rated humor. 
4. When responding to an incongruent meme (e.g. liberal responding to a conservative meme), factors like relatability and aptness won't be positively related to rated comprehension or humor. However, when responding to a congruent meme (e.g. liberal responding to a liberal meme), factors like relatability and aptness will be positively related to rated comprehension or humor.

Hypotheses 1-4 will be tested using a multiple linear mixed regression. Outcome variable will be rated humor. Predictor variables will be rated aptness, relatability, surprising ness, familiarity, the type of meme (liberal or conservative), agreement, and political orientation. Random intercepts and slopes will be fit for the two types of memes. 

5. Greater rated aptness will predict greater rated comprehensibility. 
6. Greater rated relatability will predict greater rated comprehensibility. 

Hypotheses 5-6 will be tested using a multiple linear mixed regression. Outcome variable will be rated understanding. Predictor variables will be rated aptness, relatability, surprising ness, familiarity. Random intercepts and slopes will be fit for the two types of memes. 

7. Greater rated agreement, relatability, surprising ness, funniness, and aptness will predict greater likelihood of sharing the meme with friends and family. 

Hypothesis 7 will be tested using a logistic regression with random intercepts for the two memes. Outcome variable will be whether or not they are willing to share the meme with family and friends. Predictor variables will be agreement, relatability, surprising ness, funniness and aptness.

8. Agreement with the message will positively affect relatability, which will positively affect aptness, which will positively affect comprehensibility and humor of the meme. 

Hypothesis 8 will be tested using a mediation model. Agreement positively predicts relatability, which positively predicts aptness, which positively predicts comprehensibility.

q20.value: For each meme, we ask participants to provide an explanation for why they found the meme funny or not funny. If participants respond with nonsensical answers (e.g. 'a;sldfj' or 'good'), they will be excluded for analyses.

attributes.title: Investigating the Effects of Moral Convictions and Group Identification on Collective Action Support for Indigenous Australians Among White Australians
attributes.description:
Racial inequality between Indigenous and White Australians is a pervasive issue negatively influencing the wellbeing and quality of life of many Australians. Significant attention in the collective action literature has investigated how the attitudes and behaviours of members of underprivileged groups can influence social equality. This approach overlooks the responsibility of advantaged group members who have the status and resources to enact positive social change. 
The purpose of this research is to examine the antecedents that lead to intentions for collective action in support of Indigenous Australians among the White Australian population. This research has implications at a social level, influencing attitudes and behaviours between alternative status groups in society, and at a political level, with the potential for influencing policy to improve social equality between Indigenous and White Australians.

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1)	Strong moral convictions in favour of racial equality predict greater identification with Indigenous Australians.

Hypothesis 2)	Identification with Indigenous Australians predicts greater collective action tendencies among White Australians.

Hypothesis 3)	The association between moral convictions and identification with Indigenous Australians is mediated by two variables: 
a.	Increased identification with a superordinate group inclusive of White and Indigenous Australians.
b.	Increased perceived permeability of group boundaries for White Australians.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: It is a correlational survey design.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Subjects will fill in an online questionnaire (on CloudResearch Powered by TurkPrime) consisting of two blocks. The first is a series of demographics (age, gender, political orientation, education, racist attitudes). Second, participants will complete scales including Moral Convictions, Group Identification (in-group, out-group, and superordinate group), Perceived Permeability of Group Boundaries, and Collective Action Tendencies. The order of the scales will be randomized within this block.
An overview of the study as programmed in Qualtrics is provided as an online Appendix on OSF.

q11.value: We aim for a sample size of 200 participants.

q12.value: We used a Monte Carlo Power Analysis for Indirect Effects to conduct a power analysis including a model with two parallel mediators. A sample size of 200 participants gives 80% power at a confidence level of 95% calculated over 1000 replications.

q13.value: Data collection stops when the target number of observations is reached. Data collection has not begun yet.

question.value:
Independent Variable:

- Moral Conviction (Van Zomeren, M., Postmes, T., & Spears, R., 2012). 6-items on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree).

Mediators:

- Superordinate Group Identification (Stone, C. H., & Crisp, R. J., 2007). 4-items on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). 

- Perceived Permeability of Group Boundaries (Armenta, B. M., Stroebe, K., Scheibe, S., Van Yperen, N. W., Stegeman, A., & Postmes, T., 2017). 12/18-items on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). 

Dependent Variables:

- Disadvantaged Group Identification (Stone, C. H., & Crisp, R. J., 2007). 4-items on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). 

- Collective Action Tendencies (Van Zomeren, M., Postmes, T., & Spears, R., 2012). 4-items on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree).

Covariates:

-	Age (continuous)
-	Sex (Female/Male/Other/Prefer not to say)
-	Political orientation (1 = Very conservative, 7 = Very liberal)
-	Highest level of education (Primary School, High School Certificate, Diploma, Bachelor's Degree, Post-Graduate Degree).
-       Advantaged Group Identification (Stone, C. H., & Crisp, R. J., 2007). 4-items on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). 
-      Racial, Acceptance, and Cultural-Ethnocentrism Scale (Grigg, K., & Manderson, L. (2016). 24-items on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree).

We will conduct mediational analyses using R-3.6.2 (Team, R. C. (2013). R: A language and environment for statistical computing). This will require the mediate() function in the R package 'mediation'. We will confirm the analysis using SEM and the sem() function in the R package 'lavaan'.

In the proposed model, we will measure the direct and indirect effects of Moral Conviction on Disadvantage Group Identification. The indirect paths for this association are via the two parallel mediators Superordinate Group Identification and Perceived Permeability of Group Boundaries. Finally, we will test the association between Disadvantaged Group Idenitifaction on Collective Action Tendencies. We will control for all covariates listed above.

q20.value: All participants need to be consenting adults. The sample will include Australian citizens identifying as White (i.e., Caucasian, Anglo-Saxon, European) and participants not identifying as such will be excluded.

q21.value: If a subject does not complete the entire survey, the subject will not be included in the analysis.

q22.value: Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) including all the variables, mediators and covariates will be run to investigate alternative models and any associations of interest will be described as an exploratory result.

Hypothesis 2)	Identification with Indigenous Australians predicts greater collective action tendencies among White Australians.

Hypothesis 3)	The association between moral convictions and identification with Indigenous Australians is mediated by two variables: 
a.	Increased identification with a superordinate group inclusive of White and Indigenous Australians.
b.	Increased perceived permeability of group boundaries for White Australians.

attributes.title: Recurrent Labial Hair Thread Tourniquet Syndrome in an Adolescent Girl: A Systematic Review and Case Report

summary.value:
This systematic review protocol is registered to provide transparency of methods and increase replicability. At the time of registration, we have finalized our protocol, completed searches, and are in the process of data extraction.

TITLE OF STUDY
Hair Thread Tourniquet Syndrome Involving Male and Female Genitalia

PROTOCOL SUMMARY
Little is known about risk factors, diagnosis, management and prevention of Hair Thread Tourniquet Syndrome (HTTS) in females age 21 and under. This review aims to synthesize the data from existing body of literature to summarize relevant information associated with HTTS related to female genitalia in females age 21 and younger and to compare this to the body of literature and knowledge pertaining to HTTS in male genitalia in males age 21 and younger. The protocol outlined here was used for the systematic review of all known literature about genital HTTS in males and females age 21 and younger using the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRIMSA) guidelines. 

COMPETING INTERESTS
None to declare

RESEARCH QUESTIONS
1.	Are certain populations more susceptible to HTTS?
2.	Are there specific characteristics that predispose to HTTS?
3.	What are the risk factors associated with HTTS?
4.	What are the implications of missed diagnosis of HTTS?
5.	Among providers who care for adolescents, which specialties are more likely to diagnose HTTS?
6.	What are some treatment options reported in the literature? 
7.     What are the outcomes associated with treatment?

DATA COLLECTION PROCEDURES
A search was performed on all published literature up to 15 March 2020 in the following databases: 
1.	Cochrane Library
2.	Embase
3.	Google Scholar
4.	Medline
5.	Pubmed
6.	Scopus
7.	Web of Science

The search was not limited by language, publication type, or publication date. The search was peer-reviewed by a second librarian using PRESS (Peer Review for Electronic Search Strategies). Citations from all databases were imported into an Endnote X9 library. Duplicates were removed in Endnote. The Endnote database was ingested into Covidence, a screening and data extraction tool. Two independent reviewers performed a title abstract review with a third screener to resolve ties.   

Search terms: 
1. (tourniquet syndrome or HTTS or hair tourniquet*).tw,kw.	
2. exp tourniquet/	
3. exp syndrome/	
4. exp hair/	
5. (2 and 4) or (2 and 3)	
6. 1 or 5	
7. exp ischemia/ or exp swelling/	
8. (ischemia* or swell* or swol*).tw,kw.	
9. 7 or 8	
10. (hair* or thread*).tw,kw.	
11. 4 or 10	
12. 9 and 11	
13. 6 or 12	
14. (genital* or urethra* or sex organ* or vulva or labia* or labium or clitoris or clitorises or clitorides or hymen* or vestibule* or introitus or pubis or penis or peni or penile or scrotum* or scota or testes or testis or testicle* or gonad* or scrotal sac*).tw,kw.	
15. exp Genitalia/	
16. 14 or 15	
17. 13 and 16	

INCLUSION CRITERIA
i.	Males or females age 21 and under
ii.	HTS associated with female genitalia (e.g. labia, vulvar, clitoral, perineal) or male genitalia (e.g. penis, scrotum, testicles)
iii.	Literature Reviews
iv.	Case Reports
v.	Case series

EXCLUSION CRITERIA
i.	Adults over age 21
ii.	HTS related to body parts different from genitalia (e.g. fingers, toes, etc)
iii.	Non-English Literature

A PRISMA flow diagram is attached to summarize the process.

OUTCOME DATA
1.	Age at first symptoms/signs
2.	Age at diagnosis
3.	Menarche (pre vs post-menarchal)
4.     Circumcision
5.	Preceding symptoms/warning signs
6.	Duration of symptoms
7.	Anatomy (part of body involved). Be specific (e.g. caudal end of left labia minora)
8.	Description of hair tourniquet (e.g. necrosis, strangulation, etc); dimensions of affected area
9.	Tanner stage and pubic hair development
10.	Provider [specialty] who made diagnosis
11.	Other providers seen
12.	Diagnoses of HTTS (criteria used)
13.	Implications of missed diagnosis / delay in diagnosis
14.	Treatment modality (e.g. Exam under anesthesia, surgical resection, office procedure, etc)
15.	Complications after treatment 
16.	Reasons for delay in seeking care (e.g. embarrassment, absence of discomfort, etc)
17.	Origin of hair (e.g. patient’s pubic area, head, etc)
18.	Other diagnosis considered (e.g. hematoma)
19.	Other relevant information (e.g PMH, PSH, history of trauma or abuse, hygiene)

DATA ANALYSIS
Data extracted from each article will be analyzed using SPSS and Excel softwares with the help of a statistician from Yale University School of Public Health. The specific outcome variables we will be analyzing include age of patients, type of hair thread tourniquet, part of male and female genitalia involved, origin of hair thread tourniquet, puberty stage (pre menarche, post menarche, tanner stage for girls; circumcision status of boys), evidence of abuse, symptoms of hair thread tourniquet, treatment type (use of sedation/anesthesia), complications of treated and untreated hair thread tourniquet syndrome and specialty of providers involved in the diagnoses and management of hair thread tourniquet syndrome in adolescent male and female genitalia. Several of these outcome variable are categorial variables and will be reported using frequencies calculated with Microsoft Excel. Formal Narrative Synthesis will be used in analyzing outcome variables involving patients' medical history and anecdotes explaining delay in seeking care and misdiagnosis. Continuous variables such as age will be analyzed using SPSS software. SPSS will also be used to perform comparative analysis between male and female genitalia hair tourniquet syndrome. In summary, we will perform formal synthesis (quantitative, qualitative, and formal narrative synthesis) of data extracted from the case reports, literature reviews and retrospective studies to be included in our systematic review of male and female genitalia hair tourniquet syndrome. Because there is differential reporting of case reports we will not be able to perform meta-analysis of the data we extract from these case reports and case series due to anticipated risk of multiple missing data. As the publications included in this systematic review are case reports and case series, the risk of bias is low since the publications are mainly reporting observations and do not include any data analysis.

registration_responses.summary:
This systematic review protocol is registered to provide transparency of methods and increase replicability. At the time of registration, we have finalized our protocol, completed searches, and are in the process of data extraction.

TITLE OF STUDY
Hair Thread Tourniquet Syndrome Involving Male and Female Genitalia

PROTOCOL SUMMARY
Little is known about risk factors, diagnosis, management and prevention of Hair Thread Tourniquet Syndrome (HTTS) in females age 21 and under. This review aims to synthesize the data from existing body of literature to summarize relevant information associated with HTTS related to female genitalia in females age 21 and younger and to compare this to the body of literature and knowledge pertaining to HTTS in male genitalia in males age 21 and younger. The protocol outlined here was used for the systematic review of all known literature about genital HTTS in males and females age 21 and younger using the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRIMSA) guidelines. 

COMPETING INTERESTS
None to declare

RESEARCH QUESTIONS
1.	Are certain populations more susceptible to HTTS?
2.	Are there specific characteristics that predispose to HTTS?
3.	What are the risk factors associated with HTTS?
4.	What are the implications of missed diagnosis of HTTS?
5.	Among providers who care for adolescents, which specialties are more likely to diagnose HTTS?
6.	What are some treatment options reported in the literature? 
7.     What are the outcomes associated with treatment?

DATA COLLECTION PROCEDURES
A search was performed on all published literature up to 15 March 2020 in the following databases: 
1.	Cochrane Library
2.	Embase
3.	Google Scholar
4.	Medline
5.	Pubmed
6.	Scopus
7.	Web of Science

The search was not limited by language, publication type, or publication date. The search was peer-reviewed by a second librarian using PRESS (Peer Review for Electronic Search Strategies). Citations from all databases were imported into an Endnote X9 library. Duplicates were removed in Endnote. The Endnote database was ingested into Covidence, a screening and data extraction tool. Two independent reviewers performed a title abstract review with a third screener to resolve ties.

attributes.title: The effect of a daytime nap on memory consolidation of novel word learning in children
attributes.description: Memory for novel words benefits from sleep, particularly from non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep and its features such as sleep spindles and slow oscillations. In children, a larger amount of slow wave sleep has been proposed to account for enhanced consolidation effects. However, previous studies have typically examined the relationship between sleep and word learning over a period of nocturnal sleep. The current study investigates whether daytime naps also benefit word retention in children aged 10-12 years.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: The effect of a daytime nap on memory consolidation of novel word learning in children

other.value:
Secondary analyses: To supplement the main analyses, following Tamminen et al. (2010), we plan to run paired comparisons using the package emmeans (Lenth, Singmann, Love, Buerkner, Herve, 2018, emmeans: Estimated Marginal Means, aka Least-Squares Means. R Package, Version 1.3.2.) to unpack any significant interactions and to test whether changes in performance over wake and over sleep are statistically significant. Furthermore, in both sessions we will run paired comparisons (trained vs untrained) to determine whether significant lexical competition is found for each group.

Exploratory analyses: We plan to perform cross-experiment analyses, comparing data from the current study in children with a previously collected data set from adults (see https://osf.io/63p2e). Firstly, sleep architecture during the nap (e.g., total sleep time, time spent in each sleep stage and spindle density) will be compared across children and adults. Next, change over sleep in lexical competition and explicit memory (proportion change) will be compared between children (nap group) and adults (sleep condition).

sample.value: 55 participants in total will take part. The study uses a between-subjects design,  therefore there will be 55 observations in total; 40 in the sleep group and 15 in the wake group. Sample size was determined based on previous research (e.g. Smith et al., 2018) to be large enough to detect the expected correlations between behavioural change and sleep, whilst accounting for data loss from children that may not be able to nap in the afternoon.

analyses.value: Data will be analysed using R, with models fitted using the package lme4 (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2014) and figures made using ggplot2 (Wickham, 2016). Mixed effects logistic regression models will be used to model binary outcomes (cued recall accuracy; and if not at ceiling pause detection and speeded recognition accuracy) and linear mixed-effects models for continuous outcome data (pause detection and speeded recognition reaction times to accurate responses). For each dependent variable, fixed effects of Group (sleep vs wake; -.5, +.5) and Session ( pre-test vs post-test; -.5, +.5) will be included. For the pause detection task, Trained (trained vs not-trained; -.5 + .5) will be an additional independent variable. Based on tests of normality, a transformation (log or inverse) will be used to normalise the distribution of RTs if the data are found to be skewed (Brysbaert & Stevens, 2018). Specifically for the pause detection task, response latencies will be measured in all cases from a marker in the digitized speech files that represented the onset of the pause in the pause-present condition (i.e. RTs measured from the same point in the speech in all cases). The fixed-effects structure will be simplified using a backwards selection procedure from the maximal fixed-effects structure, using Likelihood ratio tests (LRT) and a liberal criterion of p less than 0.2 to justify inclusion. Random intercepts and slopes will also be justified using a liberal criterion for model improvement of p < 0.2 via LRT and added until no further model improvement could be established (Barr, 2013). The p-values will be provided by lmerTest (Kuznetsova, Brockhoff, & Christensen, 2017). Correlations will be run between each of the PSG sleep parameters (spindle density, fast and slow sigma power, delta power and time in SWS) and over-nap changes in lexical competition and explicit memory. To determine signal power, spectral analyses will be conducted on artefact-free NREM epochs using Fast Fourier Transformation on central channels at 12.5-16 Hz for fast spindle power and on frontal channels at 9-12.5 Hz for slow spindle power (Muehlroth et al, 2019). For delta activity (0.3 – 4 Hz), power will be averaged across frontal and central electrodes. To determine NREM total spindles, a continuous wavelet transform with a morlet basis function in central and frontal channels will be used at (9-16 Hz) (Tsanas & Clifford, 2015). This analysis will also be repeated in frequency bands 9-12.5 Hz and 12.5-16 Hz to explore both fast and slow spindles, respectively. Although we anticipate using these specified frequency bands, we will first visually inspect the power spectra to see whether peaks are observed within these bands. In all cases, spindle density values will reflect the number of spindles per minute of NREM sleep. Oscillatory power values will be log transformed before correlations are performed.

outliers.value: Participant outliers: After establishing the final model, dfbetas will be calculated to identify any strongly influential cases via the influence.ME package (Nieuwenhuis, Pelzer, & te Grotenhuis, 2012). Dfbetas will be standardized and any participants with z-scores greater than +/-3.29 will be removed from that dataset. Accuracy rates will be averaged across sessions for the pause detection task. Participants with accuracy z-scores less than -3.29 will be excluded. For the speeded recognition task, a d-prime calculation based on hits (correctly identifying a learnt word) and correct rejections (correctly identifying an unlearnt word) will be used to determine sensitivity. Outliers will be detected using z scores (+/- 3.29). For both the pause detection and speeded recognition tasks, within-subject RT outliers will be classed as any trials 2.5 SDs above a participants’ mean reaction time. RT’s less than 200 ms will be classed as false responses and removed. Item outliers: For individual items, accuracy rates across all sessions will be averaged separately for the pause detection and speeded recognition tasks. Items with accuracy rates 3.29 SDs below the group mean will be excluded.

dependent.value: Three tasks are used to measure memory consolidation: (1) Pause detection: Participants are asked to make speeded decisions about the presence or absence of a pause inserted into familiar words. The key dependent variables are reaction time (ms) and accuracy. (2) Speeded recognition: Participants are asked to make speeded decisions as to whether or not a novel word they hear is one they have or have not learnt during training. The key dependent variables are reaction time (ms) and accuracy. (3) Cued recall: Participants are presented with the first syllable of each of the novel words they have learnt and asked to say out loud the novel word in full. The key dependent variable is accuracy.

conditions.value: Participants were assigned to one of two groups (between-subjects); sleep (nap opportunity for 90 mins, monitored with polysomnography (PSG)) and wake (watch DVDs and play board games for 90 mins). Data from the sleep group was collected first, followed by the wake group.

hypothesis.value: Previous studies have shown that nocturnal sleep (relative to equivalent time awake) is beneficial for word learning, as indexed by increased lexical integration (i.e., slower response times to “dolphin” following learning “dolpheg”) and improvements in explicit memory in adults (e.g. Dumay & Gaskell, 2007; Tamminen et al., 2010) and children (e.g., Henderson et al., 2012). This study aims to examine whether a daytime nap leads to similar sleep-based changes in typically developing children. More specifically: (1) Using a pause detection task as a marker of lexical integration, we predict a greater increase in lexical competition (i.e., slower responses to words for which a novel competitor has been trained, versus untrained words) following a nap, than compared to an equivalent period of wake. (2) We expect to see improvements in explicit memory for the novel words (i.e., as reflected by greater increases in recognition speed and stem completion accuracy) after a nap, but not after wake. (3) Finally, we predict that the size of these sleep-based improvements in lexical integration and explicit memory will be positively associated with spindle density, delta power and time in slow wave sleep (SWS).

attributes.title: PT and PG with Israeli Arab and Jewish students
attributes.description:
We will test which strategies Arabs and Jews indicate that they prefer in order to predict the attitudes of another person from their own group. 
We hypothesize that participants will rank the PG condition higher than the other strategies.

•	Participants will indicate how much they talk with students from the same group about political and social issues.

attributes.title: How an “I don’t know” response option changes participants responses in the syllogistic reasoning task
attributes.description:
The psychology of reasoning investigates the cognitive processes driving human inferential mechanisms. In the syllogistic reasoning task, as a core domain of human reasoning research, participants are typically instructed to derive a conclusion from two quantified statements called the premises. The two premises each have one of four quantifiers, called moods, in their syllogistic combination: All (abbreviated by A), Some (I), None (E), and Some...not (O). The terms in the premises (the sets of entities) can be arranged in four different ways called figures. In combination, there are a total 64 different kinds of reasoning problems, one illustrated in the following example: 

All A are B.
Some B are C.
What, if anything, follows?

The task is to generate a response about the two unrelated terms, A and C, using one of the quantifiers (8 conclusions: e.g., “Some A are C”, “No C are A”, etc.) or to conclude that “no logically valid conclusion” – NVC for short – follows. Thus, in total, there are 9 different response options/ conclusions. Syllogisms where a conclusion with a quantifier logically follows are called valid and those were NVC is the logically correct response are called invalid syllogisms (which is the case in the given example).

In recent studies, we were able demonstrate that people greatly differ in their tendency to respond “NVC” (e.g., Ragni, Dames, Brand, & Riesterer, 2019). It generally appears that participants interpret the “NVC” response option differently: For instance, while some participants seem to avoid this response option (possibly feeling uncomfortable concluding that one can infer nothing given two premises), others appear to assign it a meaning of “I give up” and use it frequently instead. From a diagnostical view, this is highly problematic: The way the syllogistic reasoning task is currently designed and used, individuals’ interpretations of a response option differ, thus, contaminating the actual measure of interest (individuals’ reasoning processes or abilities). This is particularly problematic in view of the fact that about two thirds of the 64 syllogism schemes do not allow for a logical conclusion, i.e. NVC is the logically correct answer. Thus, in many cases the logically correct answer coincides with the answer that is often chosen when respondents give up or avoid the NVC response options. This observation immediately raises the question whether an additional opt-out response option (e.g., “I tried my best, but I could not find a conclusion”) would solve this issue and provide a better estimation of participants’ actual reasoning processes.

The current experiment investigates this question by presenting half of the participants with only the 9 possible conclusions (control group) and the other half with an opt-out response option in addition to the classic 9 conclusions (experimental group).

q1.value: Hannah Dames, Marco Ragni, Niklas Schulte

q2.value:
Control Group = 9 response options/ conclusions (8 conclusions required for valid syllogisms + NVC required for invalid syllogisms)

Experimental Group = 9 response options + 1 “I don’t know” response option

H1: In the experimental group, the relative frequency of “I don’t know” responses is significantly higher than 0%. 

H2a: The likelihood to respond NVC (“no valid conclusion”) significantly differs between the control and the experimental group.

H2b: The effect of group (control vs. experimental) is stronger for invalid than for valid syllogisms.  

Furthermore, we will exploratively investigate whether the likelihood to give a correct response changes between the control and the experimental group.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The experiment has 2x2 mixed design with group (control vs. experimental condition) manipulated between participants and validity (valid vs. invalid) of the syllogisms manipulated within participants. 

Stimuli and Task
Participants’ task is to generate a conclusion for 13 syllogisms (see introductory description) consisting of two premises each (selection task design). The syllogisms used in this experiment are: AE4, AO2, IA2, OE1, IE3, IE4, AA3, OI4, OE2, OE4, OO3, OO4, AE1. The selection is based on prior experiments and consists of both valid and invalid as well as more and less difficult problems. The abbreviations A, I, E, and O denote the quantifiers “All”, “Some”, “No”, and “Some... not”; numbers reflect the syllogistic figure, i.e., the order of terms in the premises (for an overview, see Khemlani & Johnson-Laird, 2012), as well as “ac” and “ca” representing the order of terms in the conclusion).

All participants are told to assume the premises to be true and are instructed to draw a conclusion only if it necessarily followed from the two premises. The content of the syllogisms depicts professions of groups of people where we assume no influence of content on the believability of premises. 

Procedure
Each trial starts with the presentation the premises and the nine response options. For the experimental group only, an additional response option is displayed: “Ich habe mein bestes gegeben, aber ich komme auf keine Lösung” (German; Engl. translation: “I tried my best, but I could not find a conclusion”). 

Participants select one of the response options using the mouse and then press a “continue”-button to confirm their selec¬tion. There is no response deadline and no feedback is given. Overall, the experiment consists of an example task (solution is provided) and 13 trials each. At the end of the experiments, participants answer additional questions about themselves and are debriefed.

q7.value: Participants are randomly assigned to either the control condition or the experimental condition. The order of the 13 syllogisms, content of the premises, and order of the pre¬sented conclusions is random per partici¬pant.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: Data collection ist still running and not completed yet. We have thus not analyzed the data as the data collection is not completed.

question.value: Participants are recruited via a local web-based study participation platform where participants can sign up for studies they qualify for on the system. In addition, participants are recruited via posters, hand-outs, social media, forums, and email. In exchange for their participation, participants receive study credits (the expected duration is 30 minutes).
Validity of a syllogism (valid vs. invalid) within participants, experimental (9 conclusions + additional opt-out response option) vs. control (9 conclusions only) condition (between)

We measure the response distributions over all response options – in particular, we measure whether participants respond NVC or not (both groups; H2) and whether they use the additional response option or not (experimental group only; H1). In addition, we collect reaction times and errors rates for explorative analyses.  
Moreover, we collect some demographic data (e.g., age, gender) and information on participants’ motivation at the end of the experiment. However, we do not use these measures in confirmatory analyses. Last, using post-experimental questions, we assess whether participants have knowledge of logic or were trained in logic.
For a descriptive analysis, we will calculate the percentage of correct responses and mean reaction time for all response options and design cells separately for both groups.

For H1, we will use an exact binomial test for the null hypothesis that the proportion of “I tried my best, but I could not find a conclusion” is zero. 

For H2a and H2b, we will fit a generalized mixed model (GLMM) on whether participants’ responded NVC (1) or not (0) with group (control vs. experimental, between), validity (valid vs. invalid, within), and the corresponding interaction as fixed effects with binomial errors distribution and a logistic linking function. The random effects structure for our design is given by random intercepts for participants and syllogisms and by-participant random slopes for validity as well as by-syllogism random slopes for group. In case the model does not converge, we will first remove the correlation among random slopes and intercepts (start by-participant random slopes for validity) and then stepwise remove random slopes (beginning with by-participant random slope) until the model converges.

q19.value:
For H1, we will calculate the exact binomial test with alpha = 0.05 (one-tailed). 
For the GLMM analyses, we will use LRTs and parametric bootstrapping to obtain p-values and confidence intervals.

Generally, we will regard p-values less than .050 as criteria for statistically significant results.

q20.value: Only partici¬pants that finish the whole experiment and agree to the usage of their data are taken into consideration. Participants with highly unrealistic completion times of below three minutes and  more than three standard deviations  below the mean response time and high prior knowledge of the problems as well as those that received a formal training in logics are excluded from the analyses.

q21.value: Participants who do not complete the whole experiment will be excluded and replaced.

q22.value: We will exploratively investigate whether the likelihood to give a correct response changes between the control and the experimental group.

q23.value:
References
Khemlani, S., & Johnson-Laird, P. N. (2012). Theories of the syllogism: A meta-analysis. Psychological Bulletin, 138(3), 427-457.

Ragni, M.*, Dames, H.*, Brand, D., & Riesterer, N. (2019). When Does a Reasoner Respond: Nothing Follows?. In Proceedings of the 41st Annual Conference of the Cognitive Science Society. Montreal: Cognitive Science Society. *authors contributed equally

registration_responses.q2:
Control Group = 9 response options/ conclusions (8 conclusions required for valid syllogisms + NVC required for invalid syllogisms)

Experimental Group = 9 response options + 1 “I don’t know” response option

H1: In the experimental group, the relative frequency of “I don’t know” responses is significantly higher than 0%. 

H2a: The likelihood to respond NVC (“no valid conclusion”) significantly differs between the control and the experimental group.

H2b: The effect of group (control vs. experimental) is stronger for invalid than for valid syllogisms.  

Furthermore, we will exploratively investigate whether the likelihood to give a correct response changes between the control and the experimental group.

registration_responses.q6.question:
The experiment has 2x2 mixed design with group (control vs. experimental condition) manipulated between participants and validity (valid vs. invalid) of the syllogisms manipulated within participants. 

Stimuli and Task
Participants’ task is to generate a conclusion for 13 syllogisms (see introductory description) consisting of two premises each (selection task design). The syllogisms used in this experiment are: AE4, AO2, IA2, OE1, IE3, IE4, AA3, OI4, OE2, OE4, OO3, OO4, AE1. The selection is based on prior experiments and consists of both valid and invalid as well as more and less difficult problems. The abbreviations A, I, E, and O denote the quantifiers “All”, “Some”, “No”, and “Some... not”; numbers reflect the syllogistic figure, i.e., the order of terms in the premises (for an overview, see Khemlani & Johnson-Laird, 2012), as well as “ac” and “ca” representing the order of terms in the conclusion).

All participants are told to assume the premises to be true and are instructed to draw a conclusion only if it necessarily followed from the two premises. The content of the syllogisms depicts professions of groups of people where we assume no influence of content on the believability of premises. 

Procedure
Each trial starts with the presentation the premises and the nine response options. For the experimental group only, an additional response option is displayed: “Ich habe mein bestes gegeben, aber ich komme auf keine Lösung” (German; Engl. translation: “I tried my best, but I could not find a conclusion”). 

Participants select one of the response options using the mouse and then press a “continue”-button to confirm their selec¬tion. There is no response deadline and no feedback is given. Overall, the experiment consists of an example task (solution is provided) and 13 trials each. At the end of the experiments, participants answer additional questions about themselves and are debriefed.

attributes.title: Experiments on the syntactic flexibility of idioms
attributes.description: This is part of a linguistic research project. We investigate the syntactic flexibility of idiomatic VPs in German and English. This preregistration concerns the fifth experiment on German.

q1.value: Marta Wierzba, J M M Brown, Prof. Gisbert Fanselow

q2.value:
In this experiment, we collect compositionality ratings of German VP idioms as well as acceptability ratings of these idioms in various syntactic constructions. We also test the acceptability of non-idiomatic VPs in the same constructions.

Research questions:
    • What determines the syntactic flexibility of idiom parts?
    • Is it an idiom-specific property, or does the generalization extend to non-idioms?

All correlations mentioned in the hypotheses below refer to positive linear correlation of relative acceptability values (= mean acceptability difference between the canonical baseline and the other test conditions, calculated for each idiom/condition).

Hypotheses based on our previous findings for idiomatic VPs:
    • (H1) There is some crucial property which idiomatic transitive VPs possess to varying degrees, and which increases the acceptability of the conditions prefield, LD, and scrambling.
        ◦ Prediction: Significant correlation between prefield, LD, and scrambling.
    • (H2) This crucial property is referentiality/specificity of the internal argument, and the condition anaphor is a proxy of it.
        ◦ Prediction: Significant correlation between anaphor and prefield/LD/scrambling.
    • (H3) This property does not generally make passive and nominalization more acceptable.
        ◦ Prediction: Significantly less strong correlation between anaphor and passive/nominalization (in comparison to the correlation with the structures listed above).
    • (H4) The compositionality rating task (as defined in the previous experiment, i.e., whether both idiom parts contribute an individual meaning or not) is either a worse proxy of the crucial property, or it measures something else entirely.
        ◦ Prediction: Significantly less strong correlation between compositionality and prefield/LD/scrambling than between anaphor and prefield/LD/scrambling.

Extrapolating to non-idiomatic VPs:
    • (H5): The pattern observed for syntactic flexibility of idiomatic VPs (i.e., dependence on referentiality/specificity of the internal argument) is more general and extends to non-idiomatic transitive VPs. This should become visible when non-idiomatic VPs with varying degrees of referentiality of the internal argument are tested.
        ◦ Prediction: The same patterns as predicted by hypotheses (H1-3) above for idiomatic VPs are also found for non-idiomatic VPs.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: Comment: there is no personnel interacting directly the participants (online questionnaire).

question.value:
Design:
Eight structures (within items)
    • canonical (baseline)
    • anaphor
    • prefield
    • left dislocation
    • scrambling
    • passive
    • nominalization
    • wh-question

Two groups of VPs (between items):
    • idiomatic (8 with definite direct object, 8 indefinite)
    • non-idiomatic (4 definite, 4 indefinite, 8 incorporated)
    • --> 32 items in sum

These distributions of def./indef./incorporated items were chosen based on the conjectures that referentiality could be a crucial factor, and that DPs within idioms are less likely to be referential even when they are definite; we are adding the non-idiomatic VPs with an incorporated object in the expectation to thus obtain a comparable distribution wrt. to referentiality within idiomatic and non-idiomatic items.

Participants and procedure:
60 participants will be tested. Each of them will see each item in four conditions. This way, we will obtain 30 data points per item/condition (comparable to the sample size in each of our previous experiments). We will also collect ratings of perceived compositionality from each participant, by asking for each idiom part [V/DP]: "Does this part have an individual meaning in this idiom?" (In the previous experiment we asked a single question about the whole idiom: "Does each part contribute an individual meaning?" The two-part question will allow for a more fine-grained analysis.)

Procedure:
    1. Compositionality ratings for 16 idioms (~ 10 min)
    2. Two independent questionnaires, for a different experiment (~ 20-30 min)
    3. Acceptability ratings for the idiomatic/non-idiomatic items listed above, 128 stimuli per participant (~ 30 min)

(see the attached document for a schematic example item.

q7.value:
- For each item, the eight conditions will be divided randomly into two groups (this will be done only once). Each participant will see one of these groups; i.e., there will be two lists, each with four conditions per item.
- Participants will be assigned randomly to the two lists.
- The order of stimuli will be randomized. 8 different randomized variants will be used.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited via prolific.ac. The following filters will be used:
- Sex (equal distribution m/f)
- Country of Birth (Germany)
- Current Country of Residence (Germany)
- First Language (German)
- Were you raised monolingual? (yes)
- Previous Studies (excluding participants who took part in a previous experiment of this project)

The estimated participation duration is 75 minutes. Participants will receive 9 pounds.

Procedure:
    1. Familiarity and compositionality ratings for 16 idioms (~ 15 min)
    2. Two independent questionnaires, for a different experiment (~ 30 min)
    3. Acceptability ratings for the idiomatic/non-idiomatic items listed above, 128 stimuli per participant (~ 30 min)

If a participant responds with "I am not familiar with this idiom" in the first task, their data points for this idiom in the compositional and acceptability rating tasks will be excluded from analysis.

q11.value: We are testing 60 participants. This way, we will obtain up to 60 compositionality ratings per idiom (except for the idioms that participants are not familiar with). As for the acceptability ratings, each participant will rate each item in 4 out of 8 conditions. We will therefore obtain 30 ratings per item/condition.

q12.value: We are planning to analyze the correlation between mean ratings for item/condition. In our previous experiments, these means were based on 24-48 datapoints. Based on the results of the previous experiments (in which the same items were tested several times), we estimate that 30 datapoints are sufficient for a robust/stable estimate.

question.value:
Factor syntactic structure (manipulated within items),  8 levels:
    • canonical (baseline)
    • anaphor
    • prefield
    • left dislocation
    • scrambling
    • passive
    • nominalization
    • wh-question

Factor "type of VP" (between items), two levels:
    • idiomatic (8 with definite direct object, 8 indefinite)
    • non-idiomatic (4 definite, 4 indefinite, 8 incorporated)

1. a familiarity rating for the idioms ("Are you familiar with this idiom?" - "yes"/"no")
2. two compositionality ratings per idiom (only for those familiar to the participants), one for each part (verb / object), measured by asking for each idiom part [V/DP]: "Does this part have an individual meaning in this idiom?" ("yes, namely: ..." / "yes, but I cannot really express the meaning" / no"). 
3. acceptability ratings (1-7) for sentences containing the idiomatic/non-idiomatic VP in the different syntactic constructions
We will calculate a mean relative acceptability rating for each item/condition based on the raw acceptability ratings. This will be described in more detail in the analysis plan section.

Planned analysis steps:
    1. Calculate the relative acceptability per test condition / idiom by subtracting its mean acceptability rating from the mean acceptability rating for the canonical baseline.
    2. Calculate the correlation between the relative acceptability of the anaphor condition and all other test conditions for two subsets of the data: (i) idiomatic VPs, (ii) non-idiomatic VPs.
        ◦ For evaluating the hypotheses above, Pearson's r (testing for linear correlation) will be used.
For further exploratory analysis (testing for potential non-linear monotonic correlations), Spearman's rho and Kendall's tau will also be calcluated.
        ◦ For testing whether a correlation is significantly weaker than another, Fisher's Z comparisons will be used.
    3. The compositionality ratings will be analyzed as follows:
        ◦ For evaluation of hypothesis H4, a compositionality value will be calculated for each idiom based on the compositionality rating task: number of cases in which the response was "yes" to both questions [V/DP] devided by total number of other response patterns.
We will also do an additional exploratory analysis in which we consider a "yes" response to the DP question as a sufficient condition for categorizing it as compositional.
        ◦ If a participant indicates that they are not familiar with an idiom, their data points for this idiom in the acceptability rating task will be excluded from analysis.
